results.content:
My terms of admiration for Max and this course would be no different from those expressed by other students here.

i was drawn to this course coz there was a promise of building a complete application. but as a i walk down the pathway of this course, i'm gonna have to say it has far surpassed my expectations. i came to this course without being familiar with the ng2 framework, but Max has gone to great lengths to explain the fundamentals of ng2 and how it fits together with Node and Mongo. I believe Max is perhaps one of the very few trainers who can walk this tightrope of practice and theory with such grace it's hard to turn your gaze away from it.

Max, there's a lot i'm learning through this course. Thank you for putting this together, and also thank you for v much your kind support on this course. I look forward to being a part of other end-to-end courses from you.

results.content:
Coming from "Angular 6 (formerly Angular 2) - The Complete Guide", this course was very fun to follow and it complemented the content I obtained from Angular course very well. The instructor is a very knowledgable person, giving you different approaches on particular problems, and also stating the reasons why he chooses which one.

As far as the content of the course is concerned, I think it was broad enough. You will learn concepts that you may need in any app that you are likely to build, and then some. He even showed two different ways of deployment, which was a huge plus for me since I hate the deployment process for some reason, though I used heroku and github pages instead of aws, but the stuff that was taught was still applicable to some extent.

Overall, I totally recommend this course; 5/5.

This course covers very interesting topics: Angular, Node / Express and MongoDB. However, compared to the first courses  with Max, I noticed poor interest in solving problems for the course assistant: at the precise request there was always the usual answer copied and pasted several times! At the beginning of the course there were several mistakes thta I solved thanks to the help of other students!
Consider these things if you decide to buy this course

response.content:
Hi Elio - I couldn't find a single question from you in the Q&A section, I'm sorry if I couldn't provide the help you expected.
In general though, I indeed often point students at the code that I do provide for this course. If you got an error with your code, comparing it to the attached course code simply is the quickest and easiest way for you to find + fix it.
Whenever an issue is not really course-code related (but still course-related and not focused on some personal project), I of course do my best to help as you certainly noticed.

results.content:
I'd already completed Max's Angular course.
This course complemented that course in that it integrated with a RESTful API which i was after. The fact that node.js was used to manage this API was a bonus. I'd never used Mongo DB so that was a bonus, as was Mongoose as a wrapper around the db client.
The deployment section was great as it went thru deploying the server and client as separate apps or a consolidated app.
The fact that the 'old' course notes are included as well is useful as that went  thru the process of using Mongo DB as a local server/client wheras the current course uses Mongo as a cloud service.

Max is totally engaging and knowledgeable - you can tell he enjoys working with Angular and his experience with it shines thru. All steps in developing the sample app are worked thru from scratch so its easy to follow. The pace of the course is perfect with more time spent on those concepts requiring more time. A perfect course to accompany his 'Complete Guide to Angular' course.

Highly recommended.

One day several months later, I returned to this course to look up some information that was here, only to find that the instructor Max Schwarzmueller has added a TON of new content to the course to keep it up to date with new, relevant information.

So, because of this, this course is definitely a 5 star course.

results.content:
I made a great application, but not exactly in a way that I could replicate something similar on my own easily. A lot of advanced topics felt rushed (but still easy to follow) so I ended up just copying the code without fully understanding what some of it did. Every time this happened the Instructor at least acknowledged it with a "You can learn this by buying my other course."

So basically it's a great course, and you learn some advanced topics that are super useful, but not everything is as thoroughly explained as it could be.

response.content: I'm sorry to hear you're not 100% happy with the course. I don't remember pointing you at other courses a couple of times but I do answer a lot of questions, so I might have a wrong feeling. But indeed, this course is NO advanced or complete Angular course. It shows a lot of features, some of them being advanced (image upload). But most of all, it's about giving a clear idea of how Node + Express + MongoDB + Angular work together and giving you the tools to then apply this knowledge to your own apps. If you want to learn more about Angular's features, I indeed got a specialized course for that.

results.content: A nice course, a GUIDE actually, to show a certain approach to building a MEAN stack. This course, in my opinion is of informative nature, to show the connections in the MEAN stack, and not an instruction course on how to build a certain kind of application. Of course, since MEAN frameworks are constantly updated with breaking changes (more often today than ever), it is important to understand why this is a GUIDE. All in all, a nice and informative work by Max.

results.content:
This is a very in depth course. it is well presented and if you can stay focused you will have an in-depth understanding of the subject. It is well organized and comprehensive.

I do feel like maybe too much time is spent showing the two or three wrong ways of doing things and then the right way. Maybe there is a way of providing both paths.. a short path and a long path? You will understand why things are the way they are, for example injections, but you will probably have a hard time remembering a few days later which of the three ways shown was the right way. In short maybe focus more on best practice rather than three ways of doing everything.
results.content_html:

results.content:
This course is definitely geared towards someone who has a fundamental understanding of Javascript and how web applications work. He covers the important aspects of each technology and what you need from them to get rolling. His pace might be a little fast for those who are looking for an explanation on Javascript basics, or HTTP basics. If you have a basic to intermediate understanding of JS and HTTP, and are looking for a quick-start guide to getting a MEAN stack application built, served, and deployed, then this course is AMAZING!

If you're looking for an in-depth guide to how each individual tech works, such as Angular or Node specifically, this course might not be for you. As I said above, he covers only the aspects of each tech needed to serve the purpose of the course, which is to build an Angular front-end, serve said front-end with a Node.js backend + Express middleware, read and write to a mongodb, and deploy the application. He does offer courses for Node and Angular that are fantastic! I strongly recommend going through those first if you want the comprehensive understnading.

results.content: This was a fun and comprehensive course. I learned a lot. My only problem is the state of flux Angular is in. Because it has changed so much it is hard to figure out where we are and where we're going with the Angular framework. This is not the author's fault but the maintainers of Angular 2. I now have spent much time learning Angular and React and in my honest opinion, React is more intuitive. I plan to continue learning Angular as it is so popular in the world that it  is essential to learn and master. Max did a fantastic job introducing me to Angular2 and I have purchased his other courses in Angular to dig deeper. Thanks Max for a great course!
results.content_html: This was a fun and comprehensive course. I learned a lot. My only problem is the state of flux Angular is in. Because it has changed so much it is hard to figure out where we are and where we're going with the Angular framework. This is not the author's fault but the maintainers of Angular 2. I now have spent much time learning Angular and React and in my honest opinion, React is more intuitive. I plan to continue learning Angular as it is so popular in the world that it is essential to learn and master. Max did a fantastic job introducing me to Angular2 and I have purchased his other courses in Angular to dig deeper. Thanks Max for a great course!

results.content:
Altogether a nice course, but the quality really differs from chapter to chapter. 

The first chapters have a good balance in terms of concept/background and the implementations, but chapters like the "image upload" chapter are way to fast and lack the conceptual side. I do understand that those things need more work, but i think there always should be answers to questions like "Why and how am i using this tool in this situation", "What is the general strategy for this chapter". Otherwise it might be better to leave some chapters out and just provide the code.

The first chapters have a good balance in terms of concept/background and the implementations, but chapters like the "image upload" chapter are way to fast and lack the conceptual side. First of all I would like to give a big shout out to Maximilian and the way he handles the course participant. Without doubt to the point and always with a clear explanation. I would recommend to take a course in Angular2 prior to taking this course, as I sometimes have problems grasping Angular2 concepts, but this is just on my behalf.

As with all courses you take, the amount you get back lies in your own effort. I have been sitting many hours and dedicated a lot of reading along side with the course to get different opinions on structure (Angular and Express), and to get the nuances that probably are there but sometimes not heard (again on my behalf).

All in all a very good course if you want to get started with MEAN development and a equally good instructor! :)

results.content:
Update:  I stand by my review.  I'm going to have to lower this to a 1 star, in light of the response from the author and other responses I've seen from him - and I disagree with his statement.  I am not "spreading incorrect information", I'm sharing my experience with others and providing my honest review of the course - you yourself agree that it is an honest reflection of the class in your own response.  To be clear, you did not pay us for a course, we paid you, and we have the right to disagree with the content and be unhappy with the purchase.  As for you telling reviewers that "you do not appreciate" their negative reviews, here is an important distinction that the entire millennial generation needs to understand - customers are not here to make you feel appreciated.  We are here to buy a product, which we hope to enjoy and use, and when we don't we voice our concerns and/or get a refund.  We do not post reviews to hold your hand and stroke your ego, we post our opinions on the value of the course as we see fit (short version of my experience: I have over 100 courses, this is the only one I've ever left a 1 star on, take it as you like).  My opinion, is that I do not see a value to this class, or why you think it is a refresher course for the MEAN stack, when it is anything but.  I will however, remember this interaction in the future when I'm asked to recommend courses.

[original - cleaned up]

Potential purchasers, I strongly advise you to pass on this course and take a different one - even a free one on youtube.  I'm lucky in that I'm already experienced with the MEAN stack (and its Angular and Node components) and was hoping for a MEAN refresher.  This course is not the one you want.  It doesn't cover the MEAN stack, nor does it show you how to use/setup or deploy using it.  It, in fact, has nothing to do with the MEAN stack at all outside of showing you small parts of the MEAN framework at a high level.  For some reason, it does go into how to partially install some of them individually outside of the MEAN stack, but those instructions are incomplete in of themselves and the remaining content doesn't go any deeper than glazing over his created own seed project.  Your fuzzy memory of the MEAN stack, is more evolved, than this 'refresher' course.  In fact there are very dangerous security minded topics that are expressly overlooked and personally I would not be confident hiring someone who took this course.

To give the author a bit of credit, before every single section he tells you "if you want to learn about this topic, you have to go somewhere else" and explains that he will not teach you anything in the section.  This is true, and arguably reflective of the entire course.  This may be acceptable for a $10 course, or if you spent your money to purchase his seed project - but you did not.

Closing Summary:
This is not a MEAN stack course.  It does NOT refresh you on the MEAN stack itself, MEAN installation, what MEAN really is, or how to work with it.  It is a small summary over some of the MEAN components - that is all it is.  After you finish this course, you will have learned nothing, and need to revisit another course anyways.  Ther are many better and more thorough courses on Udemy or even for free on Youtube that you should be exploring, do not bother with this at all.  This course literally serves no purpose.

Tip to others:
Anytime you see a course teaching something that starts with a seed project - stay away.  Contrary to what Max says below, he doesn't walk through building the seed project.  He does walk through what he has assembled, but that is it... in fact, that is the entire course.  Seed projects are shortcuts at best, and serious liabilities at worst. By relying on this seed project, you will bring in dependencies that will break in future versions of NODE.JS and it won't match what you need.  The seed project, and this entire course centered around it, will not help you.

My honest advice, is to seriously go anywhere else for this content.

results.content:
I really  enjoyed this MEAN course which followed the Angular Complete Guide course I did previously. This course gives the full-stack perspective and handles in a very clear way both the front-end and the back-end separately but showing and explaining the interaction flows between them. It brings you also the deployment perspective where you need to handle the build process with aot and optimizations required for production environments.

As a suggestion for improvement I might point out teaching how to plan a small enterprise class full-stack app (handling users, products, orders and clients, for instance) as opposed to it's classic client server application using a classic relational db server with a typical ER model.
Any suggestions?

Thank you very much Max!!
results.content_html:
I really enjoyed this MEAN course which followed the Angular Complete Guide course I did previously. This course gives the full-stack perspective and handles in a very clear way both the front-end and the back-end separately but showing and explaining the interaction flows between them. It brings you also the deployment perspective where you need to handle the build process with aot and optimizations required for production environments.

As a suggestion for improvement I might point out teaching how to plan a small enterprise class full-stack app (handling users, products, orders and clients, for instance) as opposed to it's classic client server application using a classic relational db server with a typical ER model.
Any suggestions?

Thank you very much Max!!

response.content:
Sorry to hear that you're not liking the refreshers (which are all about code as a sidenote). I do see your point, but keep in mind that many students take this course with little knowledge about Angular 2 or NodeJS. As skipping content is easier than learning things which aren't there, I decided to provide brief refreshers about the core concepts needed.
Feel free to skip any lectures you don't need and simply download the supplied code to keep up with the course project.

results.content:
Excellent delivery, well organized, very good pacing. Great use of slides to cover concepts, followed by putting those concepts into action.

Max combines outstanding technical knowledge with excellent communication skills and an ability to present material in an easily understood manner.

And this course is fantastic for those that already have some knowledge of the different pieces of the MEAN stack, but need some help in seeing these technologies brought together into a real-world application.

I'm hoping to find some content in the second half of the course (I've just completed the first half), th at goes into more complex object modeling scenarios with MongoDB.     For example, representing many to many relationships and constructing queries to present this information using MongoDB / NoSQL.    I'm guessing I'll need to find a course more focused on MongoDB to meet that requirement.

This is my second course from Max - keep up the outstanding work!

results.content:
The instructor is clear.  The technologies he is teaching are the latest and greatest BUT i wish he took more advantage of typesafe aspects of typescript and I wish he would have consolidated the definition for the server, client, and database model. Why do we have to suffer the stress  with 3 different definitions for the same data and having to manually convert between formats...

In a perfect world, i would have the whole course in typescript and a much stricter use of type safety.   I feel a big reason to use mean stack is we have the possibility of a single language, type safety, and synchronized models for all levels of the stack and this course didn't fully deliver.

Maybe i need to take a chill pill.  Other than my notes above, the instructor is super clear and the pacing is good...

results.content: I think they are doing as good a job as can be done, but it's amazing how convoluted the code becomes with TS. If you're just talking about typing strings and numbers, you're good, but when you get into complex code where you might really want typing (e.g. observables), it seems things boil down to the 'any' type.  I'm glad that they've made a course showing this as I would have struggled to write this on my own.

results.content: I like to buy courses from Udemy, as I think of them as being like textbooks.  It is important for me to have the courses broken down into small, well labeled sections.  This course is just that.  It is an excellent course by Maximillian!  The instructor goes into the right amount of detail with good implementation examples.  The project he chose to build didn't get bogged down in CSS or other topics, and it covered all the main points for a MEAN stack.  I was extremely pleased with this course and highly recommend it.  Maximillian's other courses are awesome also!   Great job!!

results.content:
If you have no front end or backend experience then this course is not for you. The instructor expects you to have some understanding of how front end and backend technologies. However, that's where the problem with this course sets in. "Basic" understanding is a subjective topic. What instructor assumes might leave a lot of students clueless as to what is happening in the course.

My concern about the course is what exactly is this course teaching me because for most topics the instructor adds "I assume you have familiarity with the topic, and if not I suggest you look it up somewhere." If I have to lookup the major moving parts of a full stack somewhere else than what exactly is this MEAN stack course trying to teach me? 

I have seen other courses of full stack development and I feel that making a fully functional application is the best way to teach and learn this kind of complex stack. I hope Max will agree. In this course, we are not building any compleete application so we don't really understand how it will be used in actual applications. 

Max definitely knows his stuff but I expected more from him and this course.

results.content:
It's a great course for people who'd like to see how the different pieces of the MEAN stack (or even more generally, any frontend application with a backend and database) come together. 

The course doesn't dive too deeply in the individual pieces of the stack, which may lead to confusions in certain parts of the course. 

However, both the instructor and the course's assistant, as well as other people who've gone through the course, extensively answer the forum questions.

results.content:
Great introduction to NodeJS, mongodb and Angular.js with a little mention to express.js. Drive straight without wasting so much time dangling on each subject too much. Nice & cozy, you get to work on MEAN stack fast and easy to understand, eapecially those who has familiar with NodeJS & mongodb already.

Update #1: At halfway mark, sometime instructor will simply zoom pass with his fast typing and swift explanation, it's make me need to pause the video to begin typing and recheck. It's good for making you re-reading your code to check for mistake that has occurred.

Update#2: 2017, July 27 - Course done! Beware for those using a newest version of @types/core-js and typescript, I have to successfully run production build compilation. Use the latest stuff, it's broke. I use @types/core-js "0.9.36" and typescript "2.1.5" and the build can run without problem.

results.content:
This course is fantastic. I have some experience with Angular 2 and MEAN stack but this puts a lot of concepts together in a good practical example. This course kept a real good balance between moving along quickly with he goals of the project and the main concepts but Max did explain the reasons behind many of the details without going too deep. He correctly pointed to more detailed tutorials etc if the student wanted to dive deeper but provided just the right amount of extra analysis along the way. Probably one of the best courses I've done and for me the balance of detail and pace was perfect. Thanks Max. By the way - Max's English is fantastic (perfect really) - I wish I could speak a second language that well.

Also, I really appreciated you going to the extra effort of including deployment options and walking through them - Excellent  (I like the lazy loading too). Good foundation to step it up to production systems.

results.content:
Excellent course which covers a lot of ground. If you're not totally familiar with Angular, then it's important to "type along". I found things making sense about half way though the course, through the repeating patterns the instructor uses. So by virtue of being immersed in it, and constantly moving back and forth, you become familiar with how the whole thing is put together.  In addition, debugging why things didn't work was very helpful in understanding everything - angular syntax is unforgiving.

Especially appreciated the way Max built upon earlier code when making changes, which is what happens in real life, and the enhancements were non-trivial. Very well put together.

results.content: This is a FANTASTIC crash course on the modern MEAN Stack. This course helped me quickly understand all of the major components of MEAN with enough details to get me going and learn more on my own. Max is my favorite instructor on Udemy and between this and his pure Angular course I was able to quickly ramp up on what I needed to know for a new job I started last summer. His courses are the real deal, and he keeps them up to date with the latest iterations of the relevant technologies.  I really appreciate when he challenges us to try to build parts of the apps on our own after showing us practice examples, as it forced me to work through actual examples and apply what he just taught us. I would put him on par with my college professors (and superior to a few too).

results.content:
I'm learning a lot, but it can sometimes be a little fast. My unfamiliarity with ts and js doesn't help, so I don't blame that on the author, since he said that knowledge of both is required.

Also, it seems like the general environment setup (as can be seen in the seed generator module later in the course) is very complex, and very custom. It's not really a 'install angular and go!' kind of app. There are tons of dependencies, scripts and general scaffolding that can seem very daunting to a beginner.

I would recommend this course to an intermediate. Not a beginner.

results.content: He goes really quickly and breezes over why he does things. This course is definitely not for beginners. His workspace is so optimized, that you'll regularly find yourself going back to previous videos to find one tiny line of code that you missed while you looked away for a second, in addition to the fact that there are many shorter videos instead of longer videos you can rewind. I'm pretty sure I've watched this course twice because you have to rewind everything 15s to understand what just happens since he types so fast and doesn't provide much context. The course gets better around the point where authentication is introduced as he goes into setting up authentication and authorization in your database manually using bcrypt and json web tokens. I would have preferred this course to be more teaching and 'why' rather than just being a pair programmer to someone typing code to configure things.

results.content: This is a great course for people wanting to learn MEAN stack and get a better grasp of the big picture of building a full stack application. The course isn't very in depth for each language and I suggest taking a course on each, but this is a great course to understand how all of the parts come together to build a web app that can then be applied to your own projects. I definitely recommend this course to anyone who is wanting to learn a stack or has experience with 1 of the tools used (Mongo, Express, Angular 2+ or Node) and wants to dive deeper.

The course isn't very in depth for each language and I suggest taking a course on each, but this is a great course to understand how all of the parts come together to build a web app that can then be applied to your own projects. I definitely recommend this course to anyone who is wanting to learn a stack or has experience with 1 of the tools used (Mongo, Express, Angular 2+ or Node) and wants to dive deeper.

results.content:
I've taken 12 Udemy courses as well as several courses on PacktPub and Pluralsight.  Max is one of the two instructors who stand far above their peers.  There are a few really good instructors, many that are just okay, but the margin between really good and exceptional is quite large and Max is exceptional.  If you want to learn how to put the pieces together for your web-app, this is a great course.  
I'm amazed at the breadth of coverage in his courses.  Where the course content ends, he has given plenty of references to the related content if one needs assistance outside the scope of the course.  Within the course, the examples are very well structured so that extrapolating to my own project has been easier than I expected.  Instead of getting lost in his example web-app, Max explains the principles as he builds the model.  Understanding the model is key for me, and Max has done an excellent job with that.  I have no reservations in recommending this course.  It is specific in its content, but anyone looking to combine Nodejs backend with Ang2 front end will find this a great course.

If you want to learn how to put the pieces together for your web-app, this is a great course.
I'm amazed at the breadth of coverage in his courses. Where the course content ends, he has given plenty of references to the related content if one needs assistance outside the scope of the course. Within the course, the examples are very well structured so that extrapolating to my own project has been easier than I expected. Instead of getting lost in his example web-app, Max explains the principles as he builds the model. Understanding the model is key for me, and Max has done an excellent job with that. I have no reservations in recommending this course. It is specific in its content, but anyone looking to combine Nodejs backend with Ang2 front end will find this a great course.

results.content: Max is very passionate about what he is teaching and it shows. The information is clear and well-explained. If you aren't familiar at all with JS/HTML, I'd suggest starting with a beginner course in those because he only very briefly discusses the basics before diving into the meat of using Node/Angular together. I also really appreciate that he has a camera that shows him while he does voice over. Seeing his facial expressions and gesticulation makes focusing on the material much easier as it is like having a professor in front of you. Great course so far, can't wait to see where it goes.

results.content: This course is amazingly useful and the only one of it's kind on Udemy at the moment.  I come from a Java (J2EE) background, and I'm trying to get into the Javascript world. After hearing all this talk about JSON, NodeJS, Angular, and React,  I started researching for hours about which Framework to use and how to learn it. Finally, I found Max's courses.  I took his course "Angular 2: The complete guide".  A very good course, and I learned a lot.  But, after I finished it, I started thinking, in the real world Angular 2 probably wouldn't be used by itself it needs a stack, since I read that some companies use the MEAN stack and React had its own stack or ecosystem. I wondered, as a beginner, what should I use to help me get some experience in a real-world stack. I stumbled upon this Angular 2 and NodeJS MEAN course.  This was an awesome course.  I learned a lot, especially how to setup the MEAN stack correctly, which is exactly what I wanted to learn.  I was tired of looking up online tutorials on outdated websites and there TODO app tutorials.  Gosh I hate TODO's; can you other instructors stop doing the freaking TODO's? And that's another thing,  Max has you build a useful app that you can actually use in your own projects, especially the part about the JWT tokens.  He also responds quickly, which I don't know how he does it; I would be annoyed with all the newbie question thrown at me, but he still responds. It means he really loves teaching.  I don't mean to be his number one fan or anything, but I was frustrated with learning a javascript stack, especially learning from the online examples from various sites.  I'm still annoyed at all the bugs that Angular 2 has, but it is still in RC (RC6). That's fine, just hurry the heck up and fix it, Angular team.  Just kidding, maybe.  Anyway, take this course. His other Angular 2 course was a great supplement, but no required.  Thanks, Max.

His other Angular 2 course was a great supplement, but no required. Thanks, Max.

results.content:
The course is advertised as the 2021 edition, I bought it for that reason, expecting that the latest version of angular was used and it was not!

In this curse, it is used angular 8.3.29 and at the time I'm writing this, the latest version is 11.2.1...

Max is a good teacher and the core concepts are all there BUT IT IS NOT THE 2021 EDITION since it is used an older version of angular and some adjustments are needed in the code...

Very disappointed with this course since the only thing that was updated was Max saying that even though we have a newer angular version, we should downgrade it to stick along with the course OLD ANGULAR VERSION...pretty lazy update...

If anyone wants to learn how to develop a MEAN stack app, you can learn some core concepts in 2021 but not with the latest versions.

results.content: Thanks to Max, I'll be able to connect my Node.js apps with an Angular front end. This is not the only course I took to accomplish this, however. I really recommend taking other courses to complement Max's courses. Though Max is very knowledgeable and adaptable, the course itself is sort of done on the fly. Errors are fine and teach us all valuable lessons, but I still expect a bit less of that from the teacher. There are some sections where he will encounter errors one after the other. I'm sure Max could create a flawless course if he wanted to. And I could only hope he would. Still, it's worth it to buy his courses (especially on Angular, since he's one of the only few who teach it.) You can learn a lot more than if you go to a bootcamp. Here's my app uploaded to Heroku (which was quite the task more than it should've been...) https://caralagumen-vestibule.herokuapp.com/

results.content:
I Took this course as a crash-course to get to know the whole MEAN Stack hoping I would get to understand Node,Express and the concepts of "front-end developing MVC approach" and I must say this course did left me with a GREAT deal of new knowledge and a deeper understanding on how MEAN stacks (and more in general stack builded on node &/or with a deep separation between a front-end and a back-end application).

I'm generally greatly satisfied by the course in itself, the peace was good (I did follow it all at 1.25x speed, wich was good for me), the english was more than understandable (I'm not a native speaker, yet I didn't stutter even once to understand what was said, I found this impressive to be honest) and the course delivers what it promises it will deliver.

The only reason I'm not voting 5/5 and intead i'm going with 4.5/5 is because even if this was supposed to be a MEAN stack course covering the whole stack, the accent on the front-end part explanations is too heavy, many "in deepth" concept were explained (even if by no means will this suffice as a stand-alone angular course, offcourse) while basically all the "in deepth" concept of node and express weren't touched as much. (E.G. lazyloading and front-end optimization were included in the optimization module, yet no web-packager to minimize and optimize the back-end was used/explained/quoted, in the front-end you get to understand how the whole components of angulars works and how to create services and suchs, but in the back-end you are basically left with a "this works like this, no questions asked"-a-like way ), what i'm trying to say is that basically even if this is a mean stack course, it "felt" like it was a more advanced "how to correctly deploy your angular application".

Makes no error tho, this doesn't mean that Max doesn't provide you any inputs to actually dwelve deeper on the back-end yourself, it's just that you will find a kind of unbalance between the course. 

Last thing I would have loved to see addressed is how to use the Angular code you just wrote to be converted into a NativeScript mobile app, this ofcourse is outside the scope of nowadays full-stack development but since day-by-day full-stack developers are asked to actually delivers "native" apps more and more and since Angular should be NativeScript ready, would have been a great topping of a already great course in and itself (which ofcourse would have lead to 5/5 no doubts).

TL:DR;
Buy this course if you are new to the stack, you will get an head start and a great learning curve, this DOES deliver what it promises to deliver.

results.content: This course is excellent.  I was looking for the knowledge to use Angular and Node in a new project I'm starting and this course helped me a lot.  Please note that this is not a course for beginners in either Angular nor Node, you must know already the basics of both, but it is a course where you will learn how to use them both in a real practical application.  The instructor even goes further to show how to use gulp and how to structure your project.  I think that was really important and useful.  All the material is clear and easy to understand.  This course is totally recommended.  And now that Max has refreshed it with Angular 2 final version I will go through all the sections again.

results.content:
The course was good enough to learn how the MEAN stack all works together. For the most part the course was taught well enough, and the lectures were meaningful.
There is a lot of back tracking and a lot of "you could do this but we're doing this" and not much of a real explanation as to why. Also the final project of the course wasn't really what I would have expected. Visually not appealing, and I still walked away feeling like it doesn't do much, which takes away from me feeling as if I truly understand how it all works together. 
In the end though, this course is intended for basics of how the whole stack works together, and I would say that It fulfilled that requirement.

I wanted to wait until I could try deploying my own starter app using a CloudFront platform and internal company mongoDB service before I rated this course.  I was able to do so after finishing the course.

Max found a great balance of teaching the different layers of the technology stack while understanding the structural relationships of the different tools as a whole.  Even without working on code, but only viewing the full series of videos, I was able to immediately step into code and make adjustments where I needed to, in addition understanding how the different sections of code are wired up with each other.

This course is a great value, and I appreciate the frequent updates to keep up with Angular's latest.  Thank you!

results.content:
I bought many courses from Max on Udemy: React, Node.JS, Angular, MongoDB, and Vue. 
He is an amazing instructor, delivering an incredibly high-quality courses.
All his courses have a perfect learning curve. I see the power and beauty of that technology when I learned it as the first time. And every time I go back to it , I can learn something new out of it. The interview questions I encounter, I got the answer from his courses. During the job, I run into some blocks , I come back to his course for a solution. I can say his courses are one for all! 
Another big thing I have to mentioned is that he updates his courses constantly. For example, react hooks , he updates in no time after hooks are out. It's very hard to find someone has this level of passions and maintain his courses deligently. 
Please keep this going. Teach more people, Max! Change their life with your knowledge! You are an incredible instructor!

results.content:
A great course. 
I've done a couple of Max's courses (Angular 7 & Typescript) and he does a thorough job of explaining the complexities in a straight forward manner with a mix of project based learning, theory and practical advice.
He also maintains his courses and has a very responsive Q&A section that I always find very helpful for quickly solving glitches and for the additional discussion background info it often provides.  
Worth taking the time to work through patiently at your own pace. This type of course is not something you can rush through or absorb simply by watching the videos, you have to code along with Max.

results.content:
Great course overall! Max knows what he is talking about and definitely knows how MEAN works. Some small kinks but those were manageable by Googling and getting answers in the forums.

This is just a personal thing so this is not that big of a deal but I felt that some parts were coded which later were rewritten which made it so that me, as a beginner, got a little confused. Just a VERY small thing and just a personal preference that I would have liked it more to the point but still an awesome course and still giving it 5 stars for the knowledge it resulted in.

Cheers!

results.content:
Max runs a thorough course, which I highly recommend. He is very good at delivering the overall topic to students in digestible pieces.  He seems to plan course lessons by code chunks, which is a great idea.

Yet as an ex-instructor myself, if I may leave points for improvements: (1) I can see him forcing students memorize some things without students understanding them, e.g., some configurations such as Material Dialog. In another course done by Max, I saw him rushing students through Bootstrap without explaining away the details, which was only confusing. (2) Sometimes Max writes code snippets and cancels it and does something else - this is a bit frustrating for me when I am coding along the course.  If Max wants to show alternatives, it may reduce frustration if there is a warning for such cases.
However, I am overall satisfied with how he teaches.  I have purchased close to 10 courses from him, which tells more strongly about how I feel about his courses.  Thank you, Max.

results.content:
This course teaches some great techniques for building a MEAN stack application. The pace is fast, and I frequently found myself pausing or rewatching certain pieces. I prefer it that way.

I frequently revisit the project we set up in this course to remember how to do certain things I want to do in other projects.

I subtracted half a star because the course is missing some security stuff on the back-end. I would have liked to see an explanation on how to set up a node server using https.

Finally, in my opinion, this course is much more valuable than what you pay for it.

results.content: Thank you Max, for another great course. I recommend anyone to follow your courses. I've build my back-end purely on Node.js without express or any other npm packages except the mongo of course (for my personal experience). Which works great locally, once I've published on AWS I had 502 error - Impaired services on all instances...  I couldn't fix. But when I did upload it on Ubuntu instance from EC2 it did work. The front end and back end were talking to each other. Do you thing that the deployment approach that you took via AWS are related to other packages like express? I took the hard approach for my work and because I wanted to understand in deep the logic in Node.js. At my work we write the back end with c# and angular 7, which is very different and very complex working with Visual Studio, but with Node.js I find it easier when I write everything myself and I also understand the logic behind it. I also did mongo penetration test as I know all the fields that we receive from the params should be validated to pass the injection test. Does express validate the params for you? Because I had to validate every field what typeof()  when I was writing APIs with node.js... I am really looking forward for your feedback and I already enrolled to  your Node and Mongo courses as well. Thank you again. Moriah from NL

Max is definitely intelligent and has a lot of great ways to get a task done. I'd like to see this course set on a path even when it comes to the interior of the content so that optimizations can be completely separated and further explanation can be done on those optimizations rather then while we're learning how to use Angular and node together.

results.content: Excellent course with an excellent instructor. I'm learning a lot from this series of tutorials. One of the common issues with programming tutorials is that some of the mechanics of what is happening get left out, or you lose sight of the big picture and don't understand what your code is actually doing. That is not the case with this series. The lectures are well-paced, thorough, and continually remind you of what exactly is happening at each step of the programming process. The instructor also takes the time to actually explain the configuration and project files that are often ignored in other tutorials, which I found very helpful. It takes away that feeling that there is some kind of magic going on in the background making things happen and that your code is floating precariously on top of some incomprehensible edifice that you don't know how to interact with. I actually understand what those files are doing now and feel more comfortable interacting with them. This is a great course!

results.content: I began this course as a UI developer with almost no experience in Angular, Node or MongoDB. This course covered everything that I was interested in learning as an introduction to these topics, and gave me all of the tools I knew I would need to begin work on a specific project that I have been planning. It serves as an excellent 'crash course' in MEAN because it moves quickly while still covering important concepts. Several times I thought "but how can I do ___?" or "but why ___?" and almost every time I asked such a question the exact scenario/answer was covered in a subsequent lecture. The course also provides demonstrations of how to troubleshoot and solve unexpected problems, as well as numerous jump-off points for further independent research. Max has become one of my favorite virtual instructors, and I will be utilizing more of his courses in the future.

results.content:
Absolutely amazing course. 

The way Max explains everything and the underlying concepts and the common pitfalls while building the app through the course, helps you internalize a lot of the knowledge and the underlying concepts.

In fact, I am using this course as a stepping stone, to build my own simple app for internal business needs as practice, but I am adapting it to PostgreSQL for personal preferences, and will eventually adapt it to fulfill my own business needs instead of the blog posts app.

I also purchased his other extensive course on building Node/Express backends which covers Sequelize explicitly in a full chapter, and other great topics for backend development such as REST API's & GRAPH QL, which I will further explore later.

Max's suite of courses is truly of incredible quality, I rarely need to resort to any other courses, just his collection and documentations and some trial & error and I get by just fine.

response.content: I'm very happy to hear that - it's great to see that you're getting a lot out of these courses!

If you feel like he's going too fast you can always pause, review the code, analyse it, and once you are satisfy with it, keep playing it.

So, I really recommend this great super package of knowledge, go on and start creating some "mean" applications!

Very good end-to-end course. This is my second course from Max and I have been impressed with both.

I deducted one star as I felt in quite a few places the actual pace of implementing the code was too fast to follow along with. I feel that all of your courses could do with "code challenges" i.e. you explain  demonstrate the concept in one place, then set a challenge, ask the user to pause and complete, then restart the video and show your solution. It would help to slow the pace a little and make for more concrete learning experience.

results.content:
I started out from an angular crash course of his and then ended up with his "the complete angular course" and was very impressed by that . 

I already had fair share of  experience working with nodejs and mongoDB , but wanted to go through a course which would actually show integrating Angular 2+ with nodejs Backend .

This course provides exactly that, this will be definitely hard and at times makes no sense to people with zero experience on nodejs , angular 2,and mongoDB. But for those with some idea about the topics but need a proper direction to move forward  this is exactly what you need .It is not a comprehensive  course on mean stack but  a very detailed project cause it would be like 40 hour course and most of us will not have the patience to sit through it .


This course is simple crud application onto which all the things you need to connect with Angular 2+ with nodejs backend is shown
Authentication,
Usage of JWT ,
Then modularizing project and streamlining and showing lazy loading to improve performance 

Then main thing about this course is how it shows the deployment of application in AWS environment which is a Big plus in my opinion.

So all in this gives you all the basic know how to build your own Crud application what this application does not give  you is a feeling of working in a real world application . But in my opinion if you have the basic common sense with all the things given in this course you could easily build a real world application


I give 4 and half stars and I deducted half a star  simply for limiting it to a simple crud instead of detailed project ,But I will give another a half a star for limiting it under 14 hours which could not be possible it had little more content in short 5/5 definite course would recommend to everyone who wants get a fair idea about MEAN Stack in 2018

results.content: The course is good to have an overall grasp of MEAN Stack and how different components interact with each other. This course is a complete package which helps in clearing the fundamentals of MEAN Stack alongside building an app. Lot of takeaways which you can then utilize to learn in-depth about Node.js and/or Angular. Unlike other courses, the instructor is pleasant to hear and pay attention to the videos even for longer durations. Could be better if the instructor can include another single-app deployment option/service such as Heroku or something, apart from AWS. I am glad that I did this course and would recommend if you are interested in knowing about MEAN Stack.

gulp is out of fashion.
seed project will not compile with current version of angular2.
In spite being promised before, there is no seed project with angular rc.
*****
I would advice to have a look at webpack, it would save us from restarting the server every time a file has changed.
If there is a seed with rc, it would be nice to have a hint where to look for it.
Sorry, this is my 4th Udemy course but the first one which is not up to the Udemy standard. 
I am glad to change my review if the course is getting better whilst I am going along with it.

response.content:
I rarely respond to reviews because I want them to speak for themselves. But I can't leave this review uncommented, since it deliberately spreads wrong information about this course.
Of course a RC seed project is provided, it is and always was, attached to the installation lecture.
Downrating due to personal preference ("gulp is out of fashion" - that's your opinion, not everyone's) also is not something I appreciate.
It clearly also isn't Udemy's standard to leave deliberately wrong reviews.

results.content:
This course was a really good fit for me.
I had introductory knowledge of Angular and Node (from following free online tutorials) and 4 years of experience as a JS/TS developer.
Max lost no time in explaining the details of either Angular or Node, and dived directly into how all of them connect to make a MEAN app. I really liked that aspect, especially since I was worried I might have bought a course that would re-explain what I had already spent hours learning.

There are two things that I think could be improved.
1) Most of the time, Max spoke/coded at a rhythm that was slightly fast, but that I could follow, so no problem there. But there were some sections where he would suddenly speed up, write one line in 4-5 different files while quickly switching windows. I know there's an option to slow down his speech, but since this happened very seldomly and for short period of times, it didn't make sense to slow it down (I'd just replay, pause, and resume once I was caught up). Nothing too bad, but this sudden speed increase caught me off guard 4 or 5 times.

2) I haven't done many Udemy courses, so maybe that's a common denominator, but there are no independent exercises. I got into coding through a programming bootcamp, which followed the structure of: class explaining concepts in the morning, exercises to be done independently in the afternoon, correction in the evening. This was really effective to really learn how to program. This course is more of a "watch and imitate". While I did like how Max would show how he debugs when an error came up, there was no opportunity to practice our newly acquired skills by ourselves. The solution is to code our own dummy project at the end, like he suggests, but I think it's much more effective to challenge oneself throughout the learning period.

All in all satisfied, very clear explanations, and I got what I was looking for: how to build an app using Angular for frontend and NodeJS for backend (with MongoDB as a bonus since I was mostly familiar wity MySQL).

Ich kaufte mir diesen Kurs mit der Hoffnung und der Erwartung im Dschungel des MEAN Stacks Orientierung und fundiertes Grundiwssen zu bekommen - diese Erwatung wurde bei weitem übertroffen.
Ich habe mich vor dem Kauf schon ein halbes Jahr sporadisch mit Angular beschäftigt, doch hatte ich nur sehr oberflächliches Wissen mit sehr vielen Lücken (wie mir jetzt bewusst ist). 
Max erklärte auf spannende Weise welche Technologie man warum benötigt, wie sie grundsätzlich funktioniert und wie alles zusammenhängt.
Ich habe von Max auch die einzelnen Kurse zu Angular, Node.js und MongoDB erworben und freue mich darauf, nun da ich einen Überblick habe, tiefer in die Materie einzutauchen.
Vielen Dank Max und Jost für eure Unterstützung und diesen Kurs!

P.S. Bei Fragen bekam ich fast immer innerhalb von 2 Stunden eine Antwort!

results.content:
Max explica excelente...
I am quite proud about my proficiency in English, but I must highlight that subtitles aren't as good as they should be for non-English speakers. 
Even me, could encounter that when I can't get exactly what Max says [only in just a minor few cases], I could not rely on subtitles at all because... well... there's a lack of revision there.
Just a few minor examples =>
{ 
  POF: 'Max says path',
  Englier: 'Max says Angular',
  Suicide: 'Max says Server Side'
}
I must say that 'suicide' one, got me pretty good haha.

<hr>

After finishing this course, I must say that subtitles really need an improvement.

Everything else, was great!

results.content:
Max's genuine passion and enthusiasm for teaching really helped to maintain my engagement and even fostered a feeling of excitement over time.

During the last semester of my University career, I took a Web Design and Development paper of which used PHP and MySQL.

The two technologies that I felt was not only outdated, but offered unnecessary complexities and fundamental security issues.

It wasn't until I discovered Max's content and decided to develop my assigned team project using his material specifically (with the approval of my professor) that I began to really appreciate what the domain of Web Development had to offer.

In the end, I developed a full MEAN stack web application using Max's teachings.  His lucid delivery of knowledge enabled me to carry my teams project and at the end of the course, scored myself an overall A+ as well as helping my team members receive really good grades as well.

Since then, I have also purchased 2 of Max's other courses; both of which are consistent in quality, enthusiasm and well packaged in a form that delivers distilled lucid knowledge.  I cannot recommend Max enough.

I owe this man a bier (or 12)!

The only thing that's annoying for me from time to time, is that He will walk you through multiple ways of accomplishing the same thing so if you are coding along you will have to rework your code every now and then. Some could argue that its a good thing as you learn multiple approaches for accomplishing what you need. Plus at least in my case bugs would arise when I reworked the code so I learned how to debug a bit.

results.content: I've worked through most of Max's Angular complete guide, and this was a great complement to that for exposure to the full-stack! Max does a great job of explaining the "why" of each step and building up the app step-by-step, instead of jumping straight to the "final product" like many tutorials. Seeing that design thinking has really helped me! He gives briefer/terser introductions to the Angular topics in this course in particular, but primed by his Angular complete guide I was able to follow right along so I appreciated the speed. Max has some awesome courses and I'd highly recommend them to anyone interested in front-end or full-stack development!

This (really long) course taught me how to pull together all 4 MEAN components to build a simple but complete application. I can use this as a baseline for future applications in my job. Especially interesting was authentication, as I'll need to implement that here.

The instructor was great - the best I've had. I had no trouble understanding him, and enjoyed his occasional pronunciations such as "pauth" (path), "reGISter" (register), and using "w" for v"! I would happily take other classes from him.

This class was a great value for the money.

results.content:
This course is very close to being perfect. I got so excited I finished the project within one week (with a lot of hours spent on it though). I liked that there is one project you constantly enhance on so you get quite some complexities to deal with. I had no previous Angular experience but I´m a senior web developer (+10 years of experience) and did medium size projects with Vue.js. 

Now I know that the challenge (at least for me) in Angular is not so much TypeScript or the structure but Services and especially the Observables with ReactiveX. Which might be easier to digest when you have a Java background which I don´t. So I booked the full course on Angular (plus other courses as well!) from Max as well to dive deeper into Observables.

results.content: I came into this course knowing absolutely nothing about Angular and Node and it was all very easy for me to understand! I enjoyed it  a lot, Max is very engaging and all the lectures are pretty easy to follow. A bit of suggestion though, I did not have an AWS account before this and when I tried deploying to it right after I created it, I got a bunch of issues which was because my AWS account was not yet ready (as per Amazon, it takes around 24 hours for the account to be completely ready) - so I would suggest to ask the students to create an AWS account before starting the lecture so when you get to the part where you're supposed to deploy to AWS, your account will be ready. All in all, this was a good experience for me. This is my first course here in Udemy and it definitely encouraged me to take a few more.

I have gone through Max's courses on "Angular 6 (formerly Angular 2) - The Complete Guide" and "Angular & NodeJS - The MEAN Stack Guide" in the order listed.
I found both courses very enlightening. Both have equipped me with not only a sound inroad/jump-start into the Angular world ( and Mean stack), but indeed a solid foundation that has instilled confidence in me to develop ( and also deploy) real world Angular apps as i seek to venture into freelancing.
I find Max responsible and honest as i watch/learn through his videos. Wisdom, advice and the rationale behind are dispensed and explained throughout.
Based on my own experience, i would highly recommend Max's courses. Great work, Max! Do keep it up!

results.content: Max is very engaging and a great instructor for a course of this length - not once got tired of listening to him.  I've also watched and followed along in code to many of Max's Academind videos that help to extend the understanding and fill in some gaps / background.  This course is just the right amount of content and depth across the MEAN stack to understand how to appropriately design and build an Angular front-end with the Node / Express / MongoDB back-end.  The only critique I have of this course (and it is small, but it kept me from giving it 5 stars) is that while Max does a great job of describing not just what to do but also why and usually at a great pace for understanding, there are a few times (usually in the last module of a section) where Max seems to rush to get the last 5 - 10% done with less explanation of why and at a much faster pace.  Other than this small area for improvement, I thoroughly enjoyed this course, learned a heck of a lot, feel that I am now able to take on a project by myself, and will continue to look for more learning opportunities from Max!

results.content:
So, I definitely want say first, Max is a incredibly great instructor. Everything he has done here is great, good pace, and very well done with questions and interactions with the community.

The only downside in my opinion about the course, is that you definitely need to have some knowledge or experience with Angular for sure.

NOW, what I mentioned about prior knowledge is not necessarily a problem, rather the teaching methods used in this course can be very confusing on how Max tackled the delivery of information.

So in this course he will definitely go over, per say creating forms. I like the approach he takes when detailing information on every aspect, BUT using so many methods to show the audience on how to use them, them spread out different methods through the entire course can confuse someone to the max degree lol. 

So for example:

Teaching about one method of implementing forms and interactions with that implementation of forms (method 1) in lecture (for example purposes only, the number is made up.) number 30. This is already letting the audience absorb the amount of information on how to implement forms. 

Then stretching out probably 10 lectures later, Max will show another implementation of forms but in a completely different manner and approach. So whilst absorbing more information on other subject matters in between the first method, he will go ahead and choose another method when creating a form (which by the way is not very consistent when it comes to teaching.) for another component. Like the reactive forms, which granted is really cool and does have more control. I swear I have to rewind multiple times though.

This is not a hate review part of the course, rather just constructive criticism.

I think before stretching out multiple methods of doing something in a particular way, first create a little lecture about the multiple ways to create a form, and then implement the most efficient way so we can stay consistent throughout the course rather sitting here thinking back to a different about how the form was completely different in being setup compared a number of lectures later.

results.content:
This is a good introduction course into how all on the MEAN components work together.  Angular itself is the most complex part of it all,  and you will need more courses in TypeScript and Angular to tackle it.

I would use this course as a primer to understand on atechnical level how a MEAN stack works. I still feel I need to take lessons on each component to understand each of them well.

I am delving into confusion with Angular 2 , 4, and 5.  I want to learn Angular 5,  but notice it really is just some updated components from Angular 2 and 4. Some of the examples did not work because they were geared towards Angular 2 and ES5 i believe.

response.content: Actually all the code works fine with Angular 5 and the attached source code was completely updated to Angular 5. Which errors did you face precisely?

Great tutorial for understanding modern MEAN applications.
Max really successfully explains all you need for simple Angular 4 apps with NodeJS and MongoDB backend, but if you really want to deaply understand Angular, I suggest looking for Angular 4 - The Complete Guide, also one of Max's tutorials.
I must admit, in some way I really 'hate' you Max because you made me to buy (almost) all of your courses when I saw how great this one was!
Well done, keep up with great work :)

results.content: A lot of back and forth and merging a bunch of deleting code/concepts/methods of doing things in one single project is rather confusing (just for me personally). For me, I like to break things down into simple mini-projects/mini-files while sticking to one concept/method so that I can see them in action to understand/visualize concepts better. But here (and it's most likely because I am still new to Angular) we start off with one way of doing things and then suddenly, "but let's do it this way because at this step of the project we want the user to do this". So now, I have to update/delete my notes and find all the places in the code/project that deal with that particular method we just saw but never finished so I don't know how the project would have ended using that particular method. Especially with Angular, I find it difficult because there is a lot of interconnected parts. BUT all in all, the information is VERY valuable and as always you are very well spoken. This course is really helping me understand the MEAN stack so I would say this is VERY useful. High quality course. Just know that he goes pretty quick and there is a lot of material to cover.

response.content: Hi! Thanks for your detailed feedback - indeed prior Angular knowledge is absolutely recommended since Angular on its own is already a complex topic. Don't hesitate to post in the Q&A section if some step is unclear though, I'll do my best to help there.

Very dense course. Great for getting a "big picture" on full stack web development. I understood, for example, that front-end frameworks were popular but I didn't know why they were used and how they connect to the backend. This course was a great way to see how all the pieces connected together in a real-world application.

Pacing is pretty good and troubleshooting sections were nice to both break up the pacing at times and give better insight on how to track down errors.

This is the second course I have taken from Maximilian, and I am looking forward to taking other courses from him.
results.content_html: Maximilian does a great job of taking complex subjects, breaking them down into easy-to-understand, bite-size lessons, and then building them back into a realistic application. This is the second course I have taken from Maximilian, and I am looking forward to taking other courses from him.

results.content:
Very concise and well covered introduction to building a complete web app with a simple REST API and a front-end that demonstrates some basic features of AngularJS. Was able to follow through all the lectures with ease. He is also active in the forum helping with any issues and also sometimes updating the course to tackle issues that come up with newer versions of the libraries used. Happy to know that I have lifetime access and a community of learners to help me out if I am stuck. Definitely consider this course to learn how to build your first working MEAN app. Best of luck!

A tip for beginners: I would recommend that new students should take time to learn ES6+Typescript before diving into this as certain concepts will otherwise have to be taken at face value (he can't possibly cover every single thing in one course). I decided to do the same and a lot of code he wrote is making more sense now and I don't have to blindly commit everything to memory.
results.content_html:

Was able to follow through all the lectures with ease. Happy to know that I have lifetime access and a community of learners to help me out if I am stuck. Definitely consider this course to learn how to build your first working MEAN app. Best of luck!

A tip for beginners: I would recommend that new students should take time to learn ES6+Typescript before diving into this as certain concepts will otherwise have to be taken at face value (he can't possibly cover every single thing in one course). I decided to do the same and a lot of code he wrote is making more sense now and I don't have to blindly commit everything to memory.

This is a very good combined introduction to the MEAN stack. It is very practical in the sense that Max goes through the installation and basic coding to get things up and running.

There is a good balance of "why" and "how". The "how" is done especially well, given that he shows you the coding step by step. They "why" is explained throughout, but it is a little hard to grasp the overall picture of the inner workings of the technologies just by listening to a voice. But then again, this is a minor point, and the more prior knowledge the learner brings, the more they will get out of this.

results.content: This training is very confusing for someone new to the MEAN stack. The instructor shows 2 or 3 sometimes 4 ways to do the same thing never allowing for us time to understand any one way of completing the task. Also the instructor chooses the way he wants to do the activity and then never refers to what was quotes as a "perfectly ok way to do it." There are many times the instructor "misses" things and then goes back later and says oh by the way we need to fix that. I feel like the instructor is winging the material and with the added confusion being able to use this training to work on a project is very difficult.

response.content:
I'm sorry to hear that! I deliberately didn't edit out some errors (though we're talking about 3,4 times throughout the entire course, not dozens...) because I believe that you can learn a lot from other's mistakes.
Regarding the alternatives I'm showing: In programming, there never is the one right way - better learn how to think about alternatives instead of just copy & pasting one solution.

results.content: This course is great for understanding how Angular2 works with Node/Express. If, like me, you're struggling to make Angular2 and Node communicate with each other or are relying on other people's seed projects without understanding them then I would definitely recommend this course. I really appreciate the new videos addressing changes between Angular2 beta and RC1 versions. I'm halfway through the course and haven't encountered a single problem due to outdated syntax or a missing step in the instructions. Thanks Maximilian for making this really great course!

results.content:
Der Kurs ist für mich gut verständlich, die Erklärungen sind sehr gut. Es ist mein erster online - Kurs, deswegen habe ich keine Vergleichswerte. Doch ich bin sehr zufrieden mit den Inhalten. 
Besonders gut finde ich, dass es zu den einzelnen Kapiteln auch die fertigen scripts gebündelt zum downloaden gibt, falls mal beim "mitcoden" was schief läuft und man den Fehler nicht gleich findet. 
Das einzige, was mir nicht 100% gefällt ist, dass die Anleitung auf englisch nicht von einem native speaker stammt. Das ist am Anfang vollkommen egal, weil man sich eh aufs coden konzentriert, aber nach ein paar Stunden kann das nerven. Ich möchte dafür keinen Stern abziehen, weil das Gesamtpaket absolut stimmig ist.
results.content_html:

results.content: This course has really helped me to understand how different technologies of MEAN stack are connected together. Some basic knowledge of Node and Angular is definitely required before taking this course, but the instructor explains everything in the process of building the application. I would really recommend this to everyone interested in MEAN stack!
results.content_html: This course has really helped me to understand how different technologies of MEAN stack are connected together. Some basic knowledge of Node and Angular is definitely required before taking this course, but the instructor explains everything in the process of building the application. I would really recommend this to everyone interested in MEAN stack!

results.content: This is a great course and Max is a really good instructor. This course is a good match for what I'm interested in learning even though it's way too advance for me. One think I don't like about this course though, and it's just me, I don't like how Max introduces a concept, then reintroduces a better concept in a little while. I think for someone like me, it's hard enough to grasp a concept, and I don't really see a point of learning several ones that do a similar job. Other than that, great course, and I'm really looking forward to learning here..

response.content: Thanks for your honest feedback! I'm happy to hear that you enjoyed the course! And I do understand your point regarding me re-introducing concepts. I believe that this ultimately allows you to understand WHY we use a certain concept and why it's superior to some alternative. But I understand that it can be confusing from time to time and I can certainly improve on that :)

This almost seems like a paradox, but while being detailed in some respects, I felt Max could've explained a lot more in other sections (e.g. explaining certain aspects of dependencies installed and why we needed to implement some xyz function. Overall, learnt a lot and enjoyed it!

This is one of the most comprehensive MEAN courses.  Max did a good job to use the new way to work with Angular Material (similar to Flutter), interceptor, and even OO refactoring for both front-end and back-end.

For someone who wants to learn or refresh his knowledge with MEAN, then this course should be a good choice.

results.content: This course is somewhat difficult to follow because a lot of the code examples are built and explained fairly quickly, but then after you follow all of the code the instructor writes, it is then revealed that there is a much easier way to do the same thing. So then, all your code must be reworked to continue following along, only to discover yet again that this is still not the most efficient, or best way to write the code to accomplish your goals. This course would be much better (and shorter) if the basic concepts were explained, and then the best, most efficient way of writing the code was given.

response.content: I'm indeed a huge proponent of teaching WHY some solution is used instead of just throwing the final code at you. That means, that concepts are introduced step by step and code evolves throughout the course, yes. Ideally, you therefore have a clear picture of why we do things the way we do them at the end.

results.content: This was a great course. I have watched many of Max's YouTube videos and while they too are good, having a comprehensive course from him makes a world of difference. I am also enrolled in his Angular Complete course (I am about 35% through it), so these two courses run over each other in a couple areas. As a result, some of the content in this course was familiar to me. Having said that, despite already knowing what was coming next, I like that Max goes the "long way around" to solve an issue and then goes back to show the short and condensed version of the same solution. I also like that he intentionally produces errors, in order to demonstrate the proper solution for them...although at times, some of those intentional errors seem to surprise him a bit. I was able to complete the course while building a current project for a client, making moderate changes and still sticking to the curriculum. I also like that Max has updated this course from Angular 2, to the current Angular 6 and it came without an extra purchase. THE ONLY DOWNSIDE--- I really wish that Max had implemented the CLI more often for the front end, as I find the CLI a powerful and convenient tool. BUT - I appreciate knowing how to generate files from scratch, so it's a fair, if not slightly more time consuming, trade off. I highly recommend taking any of Max's courses for web development, you will not be disappointed!

results.content:
This is awesome place to start learning about basics of angular 2 + MEAN. Kudos to Max for presenting it in a simple way. He covers essentials about  mongo + mongoose + node, authentication/authorization, error handling and most importantly for which i was here for, Angular 2 with node. Looking forward to the latest updates on stable angular 2 in the series. 
Best part about this series is, you have a question in mind or you see an error, the next moment Max will fix it. He wont give you a chance :) It is very rare that you are doing a video series and you don't get errors. His 99% of written code works perfectly in the videos. I rarely found him saying 'oops, i missed that'.
For other viewers:
It is advisable you view one or two free express tutorial videos on youtube for better understanding of this series, else you will end up skipping small important things and you wouldn't even notice. Its totally ok if you now nothing about angular 1 or 2.
If you run into trouble, feel free to ask about smallest/dumbest questions and max will surely ans.
Mostly the errors you will make while practicing the code shown, will either be a spelling mistake or wrong  import statements.
Tip: Its better if you watch videos at 1.25x. I realized this option very late, but that's the speed that i like to hear. He speaks really slow for me. No hard feelings Max :)

results.content:
A great course coverage the integrations of Angular 2 to Node, using a MEAN stack. It also includes sections on deployment and authentication and is delivered well.

Although I am an experienced developer, I am new to angular 2 but was able to follow this. It is fairly fast paced, and I found I needed to pause the video several times to catch up with the typing, but it gets the point across in a concise way, so that is not an issue.

At the end of the course I have a good working knowledge of Angular 2 calling to Node backend, using data models and securing routes by authentication, which is key.

results.content:
From a beginner's perspective, the course was great, it gave me a pretty good understanding about how the MEAN stack works. The total length of the course was ideal, not too short, but not too long either.

This course introduced me to many new concepts that I am looking forward to learn more about in the near future.

What I'd like to point out, though, is that the pace was a bit too fast for my taste. I could keep up with the lectures, but I wasn't using Webstorm, I was using Eclipse. Both are good IDEs, but Eclipse provides less shortcuts for code completion than Webstorm, so I sometimes found myself falling behind and had to pause frequently. Anyway I will get Webstorm for myself since I've been wanting to for a while :)

Thank you very much for this great course!

results.content:
Great step by step course 's which explains the entire process. I felt the level of detail was perfect. There are a lot of shifting technologies going on here but the instructor kept it all simple, up-to-date and working, which is a frustration I've had with other courses in the past. It's funny the way he pronounces the letter 'v' like Checkov from Star Trek, apart from that being humorous his communication is really excellent. Now I am developing my own MEAN stack application and this course set me up perfectly for it. I will look out for courses from this instructor in the future.

If I have to come up with a criticism, for the sake of a complete review, it would be that the explanation of the underlying concepts of angular 2, Node, Express and MongoDb are not really clear. But he explains the practical aspects of getting a project working, and I can always go back and delve into the concepts later on, which is the way i prefer my courses anyway, so that wasn't really a downside.

results.content:
I started this course with zero knowledge on Angular 2. Although i have some experience with node, express and mongodb, i needed to do a lot of research about lot of things. 

The hardest thing about this course is the course structure. Max started building the application not from scratch but from the codes that he's provided and at the end he introduced how he created those codes. That made beginner like me had no idea what he was doing. So i just watched him code and followed along. A lot of times i tried to figure out so many methods or things in his codes by googling out on my own as he didn't explain it clearly.

Someone who's willing to take this course should now a thing or two about angular, webpack, ts and some other things. Overall this course is hard to follow for beginners but understandable if you have some knowledge about things i've written here.

results.content:
Intro : Just completed this Amazing Course, I learned a lot through this course from building an application from scratch to deploying it. First of all,  I got a clear picture on what a Full Stack means and how to build one. Next I am planning to concentrate on a single technology and master it with this knowledge.

More Highlights : I liked the way this app was built, no call backs(used then and catch) which for me now became good  practise and error handling - this one special I have to mention. I always love to fix a challenging bugs which in this course, I ran into a lot of bug and most of them I solved it on my own(ofcourse Google) and for some I have to refer the Q and A. 

Finally the Jost has also provided clear answers for the questions asked in the Q and A which is quite helpful. I would to go through other amazing stuff from the author this course. 

Overall - This is a recommended course for all beginners in Full Stack development to get an overview idea of how a MEAN stack works but need to know how angular and node works(basic idea)

Intro : Just completed this Amazing Course, I learned a lot through this course from building an application from scratch to deploying it. First of all, I got a clear picture on what a Full Stack means and how to build one. Next I am planning to concentrate on a single technology and master it with this knowledge.

More Highlights : I liked the way this app was built, no call backs(used then and catch) which for me now became good practise and error handling - this one special I have to mention. I always love to fix a challenging bugs which in this course, I ran into a lot of bug and most of them I solved it on my own(ofcourse Google) and for some I have to refer the Q and A.

Finally the Jost has also provided clear answers for the questions asked in the Q and A which is quite helpful. I would to go through other amazing stuff from the author this course.

Overall - This is a recommended course for all beginners in Full Stack development to get an overview idea of how a MEAN stack works but need to know how angular and node works(basic idea)

results.content:
This course is great, I'm pleased.

My recommendation of this and other Max courses.
Thanks Max

results.content: Very good course both for the intermediate developer who wants to learn how the various elements of the stack come together and the more experienced (in another stack like MERN) like myself who wants to refresh with a different front technology and basically do a hands on that just works. For those not familiar with AWS, the ElasticBeanstalk deployments of single app vs split frontend/backend deployment options will help greatly. Max as usual is the best.
